user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SelectMultiple_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SelectMultiple_Impl(OS_FdSet *ReadSet, OS_FdSet *WriteSet, int32 msecs)
{
    fd_set wr_set;
    fd_set rd_set;
    int    maxfd;
    int32  return_code;

    FD_ZERO(&rd_set);
    FD_ZERO(&wr_set);
    maxfd = -1;
    if (ReadSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &rd_set, ReadSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }
    if (WriteSet != NULL)
    {
        return_code = OS_FdSet_ConvertIn_Impl(&maxfd, &wr_set, WriteSet);
        if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return return_code;
        }
    }

    if (maxfd >= 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_DoSelect(maxfd, &rd_set, &wr_set, msecs);
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * This return code will be used if the set(s) were
         * both empty/NULL or otherwise did not contain valid filehandles.
         */
        return_code = OS_ERR_INVALID_ID;
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (ReadSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&rd_set, ReadSet);
        }
        if (WriteSet != NULL)
        {
            OS_FdSet_ConvertOut_Impl(&wr_set, WriteSet);
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
FD_ZERO(&wr_set);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. FD_ZERO(&wr_set) is not a string.h call; typical implementations use memset(&wr_set, 0, sizeof(fd_set)) which writes exactly the size of the local fd_set object. The pointer is &wr_set (non-NULL) and the size equals sizeof(fd_set), so there is no out-of-bounds access. A Rule 21.17 violation would occur if a string.h function (e.g. memset/memcpy) were called with a NULL/invalid pointer or with a size larger than the object (e.g. memset(ptr,0,too_large)), which is not the case here.
